resource.description: The NCBI Taxonomy database contains the names of all organisms that are represented in the Entrez genetic databases.

The Sequence Ontology Project (SO) is a joint effort by genome annotation centres, including: WormBase, the Berkeley Drosophila Genome Project, FlyBase, the Mouse Genome Informatics group, and the Sanger Institute. They are a part of the Gene Ontology Project and their aim is to develop an ontology suitable for describing biological sequences.

ENZYME is a repository of information relative to the nomenclature of enzymes. It is primarily based on the recommendations of the Nomenclature Committee of the International Union of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (IUBMB) and it describes each type of characterized enzyme for which an EC (Enzyme Commission) number has been provided
Every GO annotation must indicate the type of evidence that supports it; these evidence codes correspond to broad categories of experimental or other support.

resource.extDbRlsDescrip: MGED Ontology
resource.description: Concepts, definitions, terms, and resources for standardized description of a microarray experiment in support of MAGE v.1. The MGED ontology is divided into the MGED Core ontology which is intended to be stable and in synch with MAGE v.1; and the MGED Extended ontology which adds further associations and classes not found in MAGE v.1
InterPro family of databases

The genome of Plasmodium falciparum IT was produced by the Parasite Genomics Group at the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute with funding from the EVIMalaR Consortium (a European Commission Funded Network of Excellence).
This draft version of the genome was generated by iterative mapping reads of P. falciparum IT against the P. falciparum 3D7 genome. Subtelomeric genes have been transferred from P. falciparum 3D7 based on location. The Parasite Genomics Group plans on publishing the completed and annotated sequence in a peer-reviewed journal as soon as possible.
Permission of the principal investigator (Matthew Berriman, mb4@sanger.ac.uk) should be obtained before publishing chromosome- or genome- scale analyses of the sequences or annotations.
Please contact Thomas Otto (tdo@sanger.ac.uk) for further details.

resource.displayName: P. falciparum (3D7) chromosomes sequence and annotation
resource.extDbRlsDescrip: Sanger P. falciparum chromosomes|2009-02-19
resource.description: The Plasmodium falciparum 3D7 genome was produced by an international consortium and should be cited using the following paper: Gardner et al., Nature 2002; 419:498-511. The completed genome, with no gaps, is being finished at the Sanger Institute and systematically re-annotated at the Sanger Institute, incorporating annotations from a community annotation workshop. A manuscript describing the latest version is in preparation.

Phylogenetic profiles based on the presence or absence of all known P. yoelii ORFs in 195 completely sequenced genomes were calculated. Similarity between profiles is a good indicator of functional linkages between proteins (see Pellegrini et al., 1999). Data on ORFs with the most similar profiles to a given query ORF is also available, and can be used to establish the function of uncharacterized ORFs, based on the similarity of their profiles (see Date and Marcotte, 2003) with ORFs of known function.

Phylogenetic profiles based on the presence or absence of all known P. falciparum ORFs in 164 completely sequenced genomes were calculated. Similarity between profiles is a good indicator of functional linkages between proteins (see Pellegrini et al., 1999). Data on ORFs with the most similar profiles to a given query ORF is also available, and can be used to establish the function of uncharacterized ORFs, based on the similarity of their profiles (see Date and Marcotte, 2003) with ORFs of known function.

resource.displayName: Phylogenetic profiles for P. yoelii (mutual information scores)
resource.description: Mutual information, an entropy based, information theoretic measure, was used to measure similarity between phylogenetic profiles. This measure is more sensitive, and can detect inverse or non-linear relationships, as opposed to using simpler metrics such as Pearson correlation (Date and Marcotte, 2003).

resource.displayName: Mass Spec of Mosquito oocysts from Lasonder
resource.extDbRlsDescrip: Mass Spec of Mosquito oocysts by Lasonder lab
resource.description: Mass Spec of Mosquito oocysts and salivary gland sporozoites by Edwin Lasonder lab. Oocyst (OOC): 1-2 x 10^4 OOCs were collected from midguts of Anopheles stephensi mosquitoes (Sind-Kasur strain, 3-5 days old) 7-8 days after infection with P. falciparum gametocytes (NF54 strain). Oocyst-derived sporozoites (ODS): 1.4-3.8 x10^7 ODSs were collected from midguts of Anopheles stephensi mosquitoes (Sind-Kasur strain, 3-5 days old) 13-14 days after infection with P. falciparum gametocytes (NF54 strain). Salivary gland sporozoites (SGS): 1.3-2.5 x10^7 SGSs were collected from salivary glands of Anopheles stephensi mosquitoes (Sind-Kasur strain, 3-5 days old) 18-22 days after infection with P. falciparum gametocytes (NF54 strain). Please note that since samples were contaminated with host (mosquito) proteins, they were measured up to four times with exclusion lists to acquire MS/MS spectra of P. falciparum peptides. Sequenced peptides were excluded for sequencing in subsequent runs, resulting in an enrichment of low abundant peptides in LC-MS/MS runs.

resource.extDbRlsDescrip: Evigan Alternative Gene Models for P. falciparum
resource.pluginArgs: --extDbName %EXT_DB_NAME% --extDbRlsVer %EXT_DB_RLS_VER% --mapFile @gusHome@/lib/xml/isf/TIGRGffFeatures2gus.xml --inputFileOrDir @downloadDir@/PFalciparum_Evigan/Evigan_pf_nbest_chr_forImport.gff --fileFormat gff2 --soCvsVersion 2.2 --defaultOrganism "Plasmodium falciparum 3D7" --gff2GroupTag "GenePrediction" --naSequenceSubclass ExternalNASequence --seqIdColumn source_id --handlerExternalDbs "enzyme:enzymeDB:2008-04-29" --seqExtDbName "Sanger P. falciparum chromosomes" --seqExtDbRlsVer "2007-06-28"
resource.description: Evigan is a eukaryotic gene predictor which produces consensus gene models by integrating multiple sources of evidence. Evigan can incorporate various types of evidence such as gene models predicted by gene finders, EST matches, protein-to-genome alignment, etc. Employing a Dynamic Bayesian Network(DBN), Evigan makes predictions by infering the most likely consensus gene models given observed source evidence. Its model parameters are estimated by the Expectation-Maximization(EM) algorithm, eliminating the need of curated training data. Click here to get more information.

MAPP (Malaria Promoter Predictor) recognises transcription start sites using 21 physicochemical properties of DNA. The predictor is comprised of a series of support vector machines which were trained on the 5' ends of full-length cDNAs from the FULL-Malaria database. Optimal prediction performance is achieved using only predictions with a MAPP score > 0.90. Predictions are strand specific. (Brick K, Watanabe J, Pizzi E).

resource.extDbRlsDescrip: DBRefs for Phenotype db links
resource.description: Phenotype links from Genetically Modified Rodent Malaria Parasites: Pberghei.eu hosts a database containing information on genetically modified rodent malaria parasite lines generated by many labs worldwide. Specifically, it contains data of three rodent malaria parasite species; Plasmodium berghei, P. yoelii and P. chabaudi. The aim of this database is to provide the research community access to detailed information on the generation (e.g. disruption, tagging, mutation, transgene expression) and phenotype of genetically modified malaria parasites. The database not only provides information on 'successful' mutants with a clear phenotype, but also (un)published mutants without a clear phenotype and (un)published negative trials to disrupt genes.

resource.description: ArrayExpress (A-MEXP-75). The 70-mer oligonucleotides microarray consisted of 6850 probes. From there, 6542 probes (Malaria Genome Oligo Set Version 1.0) were designed and synthesized by Qiagen Operon and 14 probes were obtained from the SpotReport Alien oligo array validation system (Stratagene, CA, USA). The rest of the oligos were selected using ArrayDesigner Version 1 (Premier Biosoft International, CA, USA). Oligonucleotides were dissolved in 1:3 of DMSO:dH2O at a final concentration of 40 M in preparation for spotting on CMT-UltraGaps slides. Microarraying was done by Genetix Qarray. Each probe was printed in quadruplicate on the slides.

resource.displayName: 3D7AH1S2 vs. 3D7S8.4 (ring, trophozite and schizont) - meta data
resource.extDbRlsDescrip: Comparison of expression profile of two 3D7 isogenic clones : 3D7AH1S2 and 3D7S8.4 at three different stages of intraerythrocytic cycle: ring, trophozite and schizont stage
resource.description: Antigenic variation is a survival mechanism developed by the malaria parasite P. falciparum in order to allow for the establishment of a chronic infection. Here we have studied clonal differences in the transcriptomes of two isogenic P. falciparum clones (3D7S8.4 and 3D7AH1S2) of distinct adhesive and antigenic phenotypes employing a P. falciparum 70-mer oligonucleotide microarray. Fifteen transcripts were highly differentially expressed (greater than a 5-fold change) with five transcripts upregulated in 3D7AH1S2 compared to 3D7S8.4, and ten downregulated. Identified genes encode apical organellar (Gbph2, GBP-related antigen), cell cycle and DNA/RNA processing (SERA-5, RNA-methylase), cell-rescue, defense/virulence (RESA-2, RIFIN, PfEMP1) and hypothetical proteins (PFB0115w, PFI1445w, MAL13P1.121). A number of short and full-length var transcripts were differentially expressed between the clones but one full-length transcript was dominant in both rings and trophozoites (PFD0630c versus PFF0845c). Distinct members of two other variant gene families (phist-a and rif-like), scattered over the subtelomeric areas of the 14 chromosomes, were also found to be clonally and developmentally expressed. Three sibling-clones of 3D7AH1S2 (3D7AH1S1, -S3, -S4) were further studied for the expression of transcripts upregulated in 3D7AH1S2 compared to 3D7S8.4. Individual var and phist-a genes were found expressed in all of the clones while the expression of a rif-like gene and gbph2 varied in-between the clones. The present data provides evidence for complex transcriptional differences between closely related isogenic P. falciparum of distinct adhesive and antigenic characteristics.

resource.extDbRlsDescrip: P.berghei expression profile - HP - Hall-Waters
resource.description:
Expression data for the P. berghei for four stages (Rings, Young Trophozoite, Young Schizont, Mature Schizont) using Mature Trophozoite as reference.

There are two datasets: HP and HPE. HP is High Producer (as in gametocytes) and HPE is High Producer "E". HP was mechanically passaged on a weekly basis from mouse to mouse and 10 independent experiments were set up (HPA-HPJ). The parasites were observed, waiting for non-producing parasites to appear. HPE was the chosen one. A deletion in HP was assumed to have created HPE (they are otherwise isogenic) and KO'd the production of gametocytes. In such a scenario the non-producer would quickly overgrow the producer. Both are cloned.

manualGet.institution: The Walter and Eliza Hall Institute of Medical Research

resource.pluginArgs: --studyName 'Molecular mechanism for switching of P.falciparum invasion pathways into human erythrocytes' --headerMappingFile @downloadDir@/CowmanStubbs_arrayData/stubbs/header_map.xml --resultSubclassView 'RAD::RMAExpress' --arraySubclassView 'RAD::ShortOligoFamily' --quantificationProtocolName 'Robust Multi-Array Average expression measure (Bioconductor affy package)' --quantificationDirectory @downloadDir@/CowmanStubbs_arrayData/stubbs/
resource.description: The malaria parasite, P. falciparum, exploits multiple ligand-receptor interactions, called invasion pathways, to invade the host erythrocyte. Strains of P. falciparum vary in their dependency on sialated red cell receptors for invasion. We show that switching from sialic acid-dependent to independent invasion is reversible and depends on parasite ligand utilisation. Expression of reticulocyte-binding like homologue 4 (PfRh4) correlates with sialic acid-independent invasion and PfRh4 is essential for switching invasion pathways. Differential activation of PfRh4 represents a novel mechanism of invasion pathway control and provides P.falciparum with exquisite adaptability in the face of erythrocyte receptor polymorphisms and host immune responses. (taken from GEO record GSE2878)

resource.displayName: 3D7AH1S2 vs. 3D7S8.4 (ring, trophozite and schizont) - array data
resource.description: Antigenic variation is a survival mechanism developed by the malaria parasite P. falciparum in order to allow for the establishment of a chronic infection. Here we have studied clonal differences in the transcriptomes of two isogenic P. falciparum clones (3D7S8.4 and 3D7AH1S2) of distinct adhesive and antigenic phenotypes employing a P. falciparum 70-mer oligonucleotide microarray. Fifteen transcripts were highly differentially expressed (greater than a 5-fold change) with five transcripts upregulated in 3D7AH1S2 compared to 3D7S8.4, and ten downregulated. Identified genes encode apical organellar (Gbph2, GBP-related antigen), cell cycle and DNA/RNA processing (SERA-5, RNA-methylase), cell-rescue, defense/virulence (RESA-2, RIFIN, PfEMP1) and hypothetical proteins (PFB0115w, PFI1445w, MAL13P1.121). A number of short and full-length var transcripts were differentially expressed between the clones but one full-length transcript was dominant in both rings and trophozoites (PFD0630c versus PFF0845c). Distinct members of two other variant gene families (phist-a and rif-like), scattered over the subtelomeric areas of the 14 chromosomes, were also found to be clonally and developmentally expressed. Three sibling-clones of 3D7AH1S2 (3D7AH1S1, -S3, -S4) were further studied for the expression of transcripts upregulated in 3D7AH1S2 compared to 3D7S8.4. Individual var and phist-a genes were found expressed in all of the clones while the expression of a rif-like gene and gbph2 varied in-between the clones. The present data provides evidence for complex transcriptional differences between closely related isogenic P. falciparum of distinct adhesive and antigenic characteristics.
P. falciparum cellline experiment: CD36 panned clones (Ring) were hybridized against S8.4 (Ring)

resource.extDbRlsDescrip: Westenberger Pvivax ExpressionData
resource.description:
Sporozoites were purified from dissected mosquitoes fed on monkeys infected with the genome reference strain Salvador I at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Atlanta, Georgia. Asexual blood stage parasites were obtained from P. vivax-infected patients in Iquitos, Peru. White blood cells were removed by CF-11 cellulose column filtration, asexual parasites were enriched by gradient centrifugation and purified by saponin lysis of RBCs. Total RNA was isolated from purified parasites and subjected to two rounds of RNA amplification for microarray analysis as described previously (Zhou, et al. 2008). Experimental technical replicate hybridizations were performed for the single sporozoite sample and two asexual samples (CM012 and CM013). Gene expression values were calculated using MOID; expression profiles were clustered using OPI as described previously (Zhou, et al. 2008).

Scott J Westenberger, Colleen M McClean, Rana Chattopadhyay, Neekesh V Dharia, Jane M Carlton, John W Barnwell, William E Collins, Stephen L Hoffman, Yingyao Zhou, Joseph M Vinetz, Elizabeth A Winzeler. Plasmodium vivax transcriptome analysis reveals divergent in vivo blood stage profiles and species-specific sporozoite gene expression. (in submission)

A high-density oligonucleotide microarray to map the position and enrichment of nucleosomes across the entire genome of P. falciparum (3D7) at three time points of the intra-erythrocytic developmental cycle using an unmodified histone H4 antibody for chromatin immunoprecipitation of nucleosome-bound DNA. Additionally, trophozoites were assessed with histone H3K9 acetylation (H3K9ac) antibodies. Parasites were synchronized twice with 5% sorbitol. Rings = 12 hrs; Trophozoites = 30 hrs; Schizont = 42 hrs. Raw data available in geo.

resource.description:
The DNA sequence motifs bound by each ApiAP2 transcription factor were derived from protein binding microarray data using P. falciparum AP2 domains. Protein binding microarrays are non-organism specific and contain matches to all contiguous 10-mers at least once and non-palindromic 8-mers up to 32 times. The DNA motifs were determined using purified recombinant AP2 domains and the resulting position weight matrix for each AP2 domain was used to search upstream regions for significant matches. The AP2 domain that binds to each motif is indicated at the end of the gene ID. Binding sites are based on sequence matches only and have not been verified in vivo.
For further information, contact Manuel Llinás: manuel@princeton.edu

NSR-seq was used to analyze the transcriptome of an unsynchronized in vitro culture of human malaria parasite P. falciparum reference strain 3D7, and two pools of field isolates from malaria-infected pregnant women and children adapted to short-term in vitro culture and matched by the percentage of rings, thophozoites and schizonts.

resource.displayName: Mass Spec Analysis of P.falciparum Early Gametocytes (ISS (Silvestrini & Alano) & RUNMC (Lasonder))
resource.description:
Gametocyte-free trophozoites of P. falciparum were obtained from clone F12, a 3D7A derivative which fails to produce the early gametocyte stages.
Early developing gametocytes (Early stage I-II gametocytes) were obtained using a three-step purification process of transgenic 3D7A parasites expressing a Pfg27-GFP fusion protein (expressed early in sexual differentiation).
Mature gametocytes (Late stage V gametocytes) were obtained by Percoll purification of mature gametocyte cultures previously treated with N-acetylglucosamine to clear residual asexual parasites.
Protein samples were analyzed by high mass accuracy nano-LC-MS/MS.

resource.displayName: Late blood stage P. falciparum total proteome and phosphoproteome provided by Treeck, Sanders, et. al.
resource.description:
Sample collection and mass-spectrometry were performed by Moritz Treeck and John L. Sanders of the Boothroyd and Elias labs at Stanford University, respectively. See further explanation in Treeck et. al.., 2011 Cell Host & Microbe, in press.

Synchronized P. falciparum 3D7 schizont cultures (40h +/- 8h post-infection) containing <1% gametocytes purified on a Variomacs were used for phosphopeptide enrichment and mass-spectrometry. All parasite samples were lysed in 8m urea lysis buffer, followed by trypsin digestion, strong-cation-exchange (SCX) chromatography and IMAC phosphopeptide enrichment (Villen and Gygi, 2008). Samples enriched for phosphopeptides and the flow through (containing predominantly non-phosphorylated peptides) were analyzed in duplicate via LC-MS/MS and the resulting spectra were searched against appropriate parasite protein sequence databases concatenated with reversed decoy versions of these sequences using the SEQUEST algorithm (Eng et al., 1994). Phosphorylation sites were localized using the AScore algorithm (Beausoleil et al., 2006) and the dataset was filtered using the target-decoy strategy (Elias and Gygi 2007, 2010) for peptide and phosphorylation site-FDRs <1% and a protein FDR <3%.

This bulk FDR prediction estimates that fewer than 1% of the identifications are incorrect. Given that a phosphopeptide was correctly identified, its phosphorylation sites are necessarily present, but the sites localization to a specific amino acid can be ambiguous. As a result, the Ascore algorithm was used to help localize phosphorylation sites to a specific residue. This algorithm calculates the relative likelihood that the indicated amino acid is phosphorylated versus the next-most likely residue on the peptide. An Ascore >19 indicates a >99% likelihood that the indicated phosphorylation site is correctly assigned; an Ascore >13-represents a 95% likelihood; and an Ascore >10 corresponds with a >90% likelihood. As a rule of thumb, a phosphorylation site with many spectral counts, indicating many observations, tend to be more abundant than those with fewer spectral counts. While it is true that most incorrect identifications have few spectral counts, it is not necessarily the case that phosphorylation sites with few spectral counts are incorrect.

Further scores to evaluate each individual site and peptide can be found in the supplementary data Table S1 and S2 in Treeck et. al., 2011 Cell Host & Microbe, in press.

resource.displayName: Late blood stage P. falciparum Total proteome provided by M. Treeck and J. Boothroyd
